review_blob: rich aroma. Dark, woody brown colour. slightly opaque. Full bodied taste, bready, with a bitterness to it, not much after taste.

beer_brewer_name: Brouwerij der Trappistenabdij De Achelse Kluis
review_blob: 330mL bottle, poured into a Chimay chalice. A rich, creamy Trappist delight  not unlike the orders other creations this beer in no uncertain terms lives up to its name. The aroma is of thick woodlands and subtle malt; quite subtle and not too overpowering. In terms of taste it made me think of overtones of rich malt and coffee. A relatively short finish. This brew is so substantial and wintery, it could almost be your evening meal in itself.

250mL bottle poured into a Chimay chalice glass. Brown hue, almost blood red in fact. Scarce carbonation. The aroma reminded me of red wine, almost like mulled wine. I could almost convince myself that there were undertones of full bodied brandy, orange zest and cinnamon. Taste was sharp, fruity, with a bitter citrus hint. Vibrant carbonation gave this beverage lively and enduring fizz in terms of mouth feel. Lingering summery flavours on the finish, which was overall quite brief. Thoroughly refreshing, enjoyable and reminiscent of a summers day

Aroma carried hints of chocolate, coffee, burnt nuts. The body was black, opaque, with a minimal head. The taste was quite bitter, slightly salty and lingering. This beer carried a thin body with soft carbonation. Overall quite refreshing but would have liked more body with this brew.

330mL bottle poured into a chimay glass. Opaque caramel brown liquid, with a rich meringue like head. Aroma is malty. Rich, malty robust flavour. Mild bitterness, lightly salty. Creamy texture with soft carbonation.
poured into an Erdinger glass. slihgtly flloral aroma. pale colour with a white head. clear liquid. lightly sweet. light body with a thin texture. soft carbonation.

660mL bottle, poured into a craft beer glass. Mild aroma of wheat and leaves. Soft head, lasting not very long. Golden amber body translucent. Bitter, astringent and light taste. Lingering bitterness in the aftertaste. Overall refreshing.
Bright, clear amber body, softly carbonated. Thin, fluffy head. Dissipating quickly. Grassy, yeasty aroma. Refreshing, bitter and acidic. No notable aftertaste. Very light and pleasant overall.

375 mL bottle. Poured into craft beer glass. Black, syrupy body. Robust texture. Metallic, woody aroma. Thin head, dissipating quickly. Taste was bitter, chocolaty, but thin. Very little aftertaste. Not in the style of an irish beer, and characteristically thin overall. Not a bad drop

500mL bottle poured into a craft beer glass. Opaque pale straw yellow hue. Sparse Particulate matter is noted. Subtle carbonation, pleasant and not overpowering. Light frothy marshmallowy head. Lacy consistency, pure white. Nice palate. Mild and understated. Delicate aroma of grass or wheat. Sour, lemony, bready flavours are detected in the taste. Minimal aftertaste and nice finish. Makes me proud to have a Bavarian background.

Bitter, black coffee, chocolate aroma, quite enticing. Thin lacklustre body. Black and opaque. Very poor head, scant, lifeless and dissipating quickly. The taste was unremarkable; like other Australian stouts and porters this beer talks up a big game but fails to deliver. Thin, pissy and slightly reminiscent of cold pot-coffee water. No body whatsoever. The overall flavour was bitter...bitter...bitter. I got a four pack for $12  it was on special I suppose id drink it again as a bargain beer: reasonable price for a beer that hovers on the average side of average.

Chocolate and caramel undertones, almost suggestive of coffee and cake. Dark, opaque body with a thick lacy head. Earthy , bitter, taste. Evocative of molasses. Lingering. Overall a thin body, not with the richness and fat, oily finish inherent in a stout. Not a bad drop overall

330mL bottle poured into a craft beer glass. Pale golden hue, clear with soft carbonation, head dissipating quickly. Aroma was light, lemony, with tones of grass or hay. Taste was bitter, astringent. Thin texture with a light body. Lasting bitterness on the finish.

750 mL bottle poured into a craft beer glass. Honeycomb golden brown body with a thick head. Grassy, hoppy aroma. Smooth malty taste, refreshing with a suggestion of fruity sourness; im almost convincing myself of the presence of lemon. Cleansing mouth feel, with a thin texture, with no aftertaste, and moderately rapid finish.

500 mL bottle, poured into a weizen glass. Clear pale yellow body with a luscious, fluffy head, slow to dissipate. Moderate carbonation. Mild aroma. Thin body with refreshing, light undertones of wheat, grasses, slightly yeasty.

355 ml bottle poured into a 250mL Leffe glass. thin body , pale yellow. aroma was metallic , soapy , grassy. thin head , flimsy and rapidly diminishing. the palate was an overpowering sense of carbonation. any taste present was dominated by the pop-rock sensation of the exaggerated fizz. Would i class this as a beer? Or perhaps a bad tasting mineral water.

355mL bottle poured into a 250mL leffe glass, juice of a slice of lemon [didnt have any lime]. Thin body, with a very slim, with a detergent like, soapy head that dissipates rapidly. Sunrise yellow golden body.  Aroma was citrusy, delicately soapy. Thin, soft carbonation, the taste was sharp, a nice mix of lemon and this brew together. Mild lingering finish. Very refreshing

375 mL bottle poured into a 25 cL Leffe glass. Icy golden brown pour, with a foamy head dissipating moderately . golden brown body . the aroma was subtle, fruity . The taste was hoppy, astringent , bitter and refreshing. Longer finish, strong lingering bitterness with the suggestion of Artemesia absinthium. great mouth feel, augmented by its carbonation which was slight and delicate, not overpowering.

345mL poured into a 250mL Leffe glass. this beer was mildly malty, presenting a watery aroma, with suggestions of bread. the frothy soft meringue head sat amidst an amber sparkling appearance. the taste and palate were light, slim and moderately bitter. a  refreshing, summery finish.
beer_name: James Squire The Chancer Golden Ale

review_blob: 345 mL bottle poured into a 25 cL Leffe glass. Slim pour with a foamy head. Light golden yellow pastel body . the aroma was light and crisp, with a suggestion of citrus . The taste was tangy,  thin feel, fizzy and refreshing. Medium bitter finish with moderate carbonation.

375 mL bottle poured into a 25 cL Leffe glass. Slow, ropey pour, with a rich, staunch, soapy head that dissipated slowly. Jet black body, a true stout that had turned to the dark side, like espresso coffee, white to mocha head. The aroma was of treacle or molasses. Burnt wood, with an earthy bitterness. No hint of softness or mercy with this creation. The finish was long, almost Spartan in nature, and seemed to be intent on staying to wage a battle with your taste buds. This beer was a three course meal in itself.

500mL bottle poured into dimpled glass pint jug. served warmed. whispy pour, clear to off lemon colour. little to no head. aroma was mild with a hint of cinnamon, creamy aroma suggestive of pear. light body, with a thin texture, notably fizzy. the taste was bland, almost chalky with suggestions of vanilla, intensely sweet. the finish is warming especially on a cold winters night.

bottle , poured into a Leffe 25cl glass. attractive dark, toffee, amber hue, with slight effervescence seepign through. a generous lacy white head dissipating in time. the raoma was rich with the suggestion of bread, touches of wheat and grass were present. the mouth feel was cooling, and taste refreshing, summery. this accompanied a thin texture and lively body. the finish was moderately bitter and lingering
beer_name: James Squire Nine Tales Amber Ale

review_blob: bottle, poured into tulip glass. full head, soapy and sustained. rich aroma, chocolatey mouth feel, robust in body. yeasty flavour with and undercurrent suggestion of sweetness. creamy, with strong, bitter, dominant overtones. this is a hearty dubbel

bottle bought from local store. poured into weizen glass. zesty pour with a light, mild aroma, suggestive of floral, grassy undertones . slim head, white and foamy, not soapy , and dissipating quickly. golden, honey amber body, clear, transparent and fresh in appearance. the mouth feel was enlivened, fizzy, thin, and notably astringent. taste was slightly acidic, mild to moderately bitter , and quite refreshing. completed with a long finish. this is a working mans beer, just the thing after an honest days hard labour in mid summer.
UPDATED: DEC 12, 2011

Bottle purchased from liquor store. poured into weizen glass. A noticeably thick pour, with a whipped creamy head, caramel colour, and sustained longevity. the aroma is robust, earthy, and malty. appearance is, opaque, murky and rich. full palate with a creamy consistency. the taste is bitter, lasting, full bodied with undertones of licorice, cloves, malt and chocolate. a pleasantly lingering almost metallic finish which warms the palate. The Trappistes have once again achieved contact with the celestial hosts and the divine realms

700mL bottle, poured into a whiskey glass. served at room temperature. Pale yellow. Nil carbonation, aroma is of spices and currants: perhaps cinnamon. Palate is smooth and warming. the taste is sweet, like honey. acetic, a little thin. dissipating finish, yet warming. Dilute finish.

Sampled this beer from a 345 mL bottle, poured into a weizen glass. Presented with a dark pour, and fine carbonations. This beer exhibits an ochre body, like dark wood. Attractive creamy head that diminished to my surprise,  quite rapidly. There was the aroma of chocolate, molasses, and yeast. This beverage was slightly reminiscent of pumpernickel. Creamy taste, rich, with suggestions of cocoa. pleasantly bitter, exuding a hint of something sour. Woody and biting, moderate finish with a clean, crisp after taste.
beer_name: James Squire Jack of Spades Porter

review_blob: Amber, golden brown hue, quite enticing. Nil carbonation Aroma is of Christmas night: cinnamon, cloves, spices, oranges, black pepper. Palate is zesty, peppery, and pleasantly warming, the taste is sweet, tangy, with overtones of black pepper, cinnamon, and nutmeg. Thin flavour with a dissipating finish, yet warming. Perfect for a cold winters night.

Bottle, poured into weizen glass. Aroma is quite bland, moderate head, creamy but dissipating. Dark brown, sunset amber hints, with numerous particles. Taste is bitter strong alcohol overtones, bitter and burnt with a sustained finish. Metallic and tinny

Bottle poured into a weizen glass. Rich, viscous sensual pour. The head is creamy with abundant lacing, mocha colour. The aroma is sweet, like brown sugar. The body opaque, dark brown, with some particulate matter. potent robust flavour that is chocolaty..  Long finish that is rich and bitter. This Belgian libation has a kick, didnt have to have any dinner after one of these. There is almost something medieval about this beer. There were suggestions of Liquorice or anise, in addition to lusty undertones of iron, earth and bark Im sure satyrs and centaurs drank this stuff

Bottle, poured into weizen glass. Body is clear, pale banana yellow. The head is frothy, diminishing quickly. The aroma is peppery, vibrant, and summery . This cider is on the dryer side, slightly acetic. Nice finish

bottle, poured into a weizen glass. aroma is warm, rich and robust. The body is a luscious golden brown, burnt amber hue. the head is full and soapy. this beer has the overtones of yeast, rich malt and molasses.  slightly bitter with a medium finish. Judging from the label  "abbaye de Abdi van" this is another beverage from the men of the clergy, I am saved...amen

Bottle, poured into a weizen glass. Creamy head, white with moderate lacing. Turbid body with an impassioned fizz. Particulate matter notable in the pour. Amber hue with hazy appearance - almost reminiscent of an orange or maple cousin to the mystical Victorian absinthe. The aroma teases the imbiber with an undertone that is delicately sweet, nestled beneath a predominant aroma of fresh bread. The palate is oily with a muffled effervescence. The finish borders on slightly chalky. The taste is tantalizingly bitter, with the alluring hint of a flirtatious sweetness, and fresh herbs. Like a number of quadrupel beverages characteristic of the Belgians that I have tried, this libation carries with it the suggestion of anise or liquorice.  The finish is pleasantly lengthy and warming.

bottle poured into a stein glass. brothy aroma, hint of egg. apearance is soft amber, golden brown. frothy head, with good sustain. taste is tannic, with undertones of detergent. not one of my countrys high points.

Bottle, poured into a weizen glass. Lightly malty aroma, undertones of bread or for some reason this beer reminds me of springtime woodlands. Gorgeous appearance , pale caramel brown-golden body, with a thin- average density. Lightly frothy head, diminishing quickly. The taste is initially slightly acidic with the suggestion of salt, very refreshing. Dominant bitter finish with a moderate duration. light body with a dry texture and reasonably lively. Mildly bitter finish, invigorating.

a light aroma with a grainy hint, almost grassy.  clear spakling body with a soft yellow colour. white, fizzy head, diminishing quickly.  
an acidic and bitter flavour, that preserves a level of humility, not overbearing. 
in terms of palate i noted a light-medium body, consistent with its pale hue. watery texture with a lively carbonation.  this beer finishes as mildy astringent with a dash of bitterness, moderate finish. this is a great beer for an Aussie summers day at sunset after some hard labour.
